Description: Monochrome glass vessel in the form of a 'bulti'-fish: the vessel was formed of translucent medium-blue glass over a core. Three ventral fins formed from heavy yellow threads left in high relief survive. The walls of this vessel are exceptionally thick. The head and front area of the body are missing and most of the core has been removed.
Curator's comments: This is one of five known examples of this shape from the New Kingdom. The shape was revived in blown glass during the first centuries of the Roman Empire. Bibliography: 'British Museum Quarterly' 8, p. 107; B. Nolte, ‘Die Glasgefässe in Alten Ägypten (Berlin 1968), 134, pl. XXVIII, 60.
